text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so today's 
episode is the final installment of the sukiyaki

trilogy on hot thai kitchen so in Thailand there 
are three different dishes that go by the name

Suki the first two I've already shown you on the 
channel the Suki nam which is the noodle soup and

Suki hang which is the stir fry today is the last 
and most popular kind of Suki which is the Suki

hotpot yes this is the most popular type of Suki 
in Thailand and if you have had hotpot before you

know that what distinguishes different styles 
of hotpot is really in the sauce right so today

the sauce I'm gonna show you is going to be in 
the style of the MK Suki sauce and mkay Suki is

a popular hotpot restaurant chain in Thailand 
so my sauce is gonna be like that but better

of course and also if you've never put together 
a hotpot party before do not worry I'm gonna go

through the hotpot 101 of how to put together 
a well-balanced hotpot platter so that it'll be

delicious everybody's happy and you know what 
hotpot is the easiest thing to do for a party

because you don't really have to cook anything 
people just cook their own things right so it's

perfect alright let's get started so this episode 
is sponsored by pine bran glass noodles which is

my personal favorites band from Thailand and the 
reason why I like them is because it's a hundred

percent mung bean start and the 100 percent 
ones are more resistant to overcooking which

is particularly important for hotpot because we 
all know that sometimes you put it in and you

just forget about it for a mix or a few minutes so 
it's very important that it you don't use noodles

that they kind of disintegrate super easily 
right so all you need to do is to soak these

in room-temperature water for about seven to ten 
minutes just until they're soft and pliable I just

want to point out a little bit to that pine bran 
makes two different types of glass noodles you

may not see it very well but one is white and the 
other one has a hint of green so the green one is

unbleached and that's why and they're made from 
mung beans which are green and that's where the

green tint comes from in terms of cooking they're 
exactly the same okay I'm just gonna soak these

in water so this brings me to the hot pot 101 
segment how to build a well composed hot pot

platter starting with vegetables number 1 leafy 
greens you want to have at least two types of

leafy greens and I always go with one dark raise 
and one light green and the light green which I

think is an absolute must-have in hot pot is napa 
cabbage this one is the cute little one which I

love because napa cabbage can get really big and 
there's always way too much so the little ones are

great cut them into chunks about an inch and inch 
and a half separate these into small pieces okay

so apart from that I also have some bok choy which 
is gonna be my dark green vegetable selection and

then with carrots I want to show you a little 
trick for making I guess I'll just stay here

carrot ribbons so just take a peeler the carrots 
already peeled and you just keep peeling nice thin

strips and I learned this from my Japanese friend 
she does this for her hot pot but look how pretty

that is now right so cool and then you wanna 
have mushrooms so important mushrooms but the

important thing is you want to do Asian mushrooms 
no button mushrooms no crimini mushrooms they have

to be aged measure because Asian mushrooms are 
naturally good in soups they boil well if you

think about boiled button mushroom not good right 
exactly so you don't want to do that in your hot

pot so enoki are great because they also act 
kind of like noodles you just have to cut the

root end off right there shiitake mushrooms and 
I've just removed the stems because the stems are

quite tough and that's it that's all you need to 
do to that so that's also going on a platter and

mushrooms will also help add flavor to your stock 
she may eat mushrooms or beech mushrooms and you

just want to cut the root end off and then you 
want to have a couple of sturdy vegetables the

carrot was one of them the other one that I 
like is kabocha squash and it becomes like

a starchy component which is nice and hot pot 
where most things are kind of light and airy

so this is a like a nice sweet substantial thing 
also helps flavor the broth nicely finally I have

two different types of tofu you always want to do 
soft tofu no firm tofu and hotpots not good you

want soft silky beautiful tofu this one is soft 
tofu that comes in a tube shape you can just use

the ones that come in a square but this one is an 
egg tofu which is my personal favorite is actually

made from eggs not soybeans but it's made to have 
the texture of tofu and that's why they call it

egg tofu so I like to have both when I was a kid 
this is like one of my favorite favorite things

to eat and the way you deal with tube tofu is you 
just cut right there where there's a dotted line

and with a sharp knife cut right through release 
it from the tube and it's kind of satisfying to

do and then cut them into about half inch pieces 
what's your fingernails ladies with long nails

they'll usually dig a chunk out of these tofu 
okay I'm just gonna stop there you can always

add more than this but if this is all you got 
you got to leafy vegetable of mushrooms a few

tofu you're laughing all right let's move on 
to the meat for the meat platter for tsuki you

don't have to do anything you have to marinate 
you have to do anything in fact I don't even

cut it because I will never be able to cut it as 
nicely as they cut it so in Asian grocery stores

there will be a section in the freezer for hotpot 
meats yes that's how seriously we take it there's

a section dedicated to hotpot meats this is pork 
collar and this is beef top plate and there's all

sorts of different cuts you can do ribeye if you 
want to get a little fancy either short ribs and

I always feel like hotpot platter is basically the 
Asian version of a charcuterie board more or less

right this third one is pork jowl it's sliced a 
little bit thicker I've never used this before in

a hotpot but I thought it might be a good thing 
just to try and you get pork tail hotpot slice

super thin but I feel that the thinly sliced one 
it almost melts in your mouth too quickly and you

don't really get to enjoy the the fatty porkiness 
of it so I figured I'd give a go of these thicker

slice ones we'll see what happens look how 
beautiful that is already what do you want to

also have is assorted fish balls and fish cakes 
of various sorts so this I got from the frozen

section at nation grocery store for the big case 
you want to cut that down a little bit there is

our beautiful protein platter now what you could 
also use that I don't have today is fresh seafood

like raw shrimp raw squid things like that but 
generally I think those are Messier so when I'm

doing a hot pot I like to just go with fish balls 
and fish cakes which are much less messy you don't

have to worry about refrigerating them so much 
but if you want like a full-on luxurious hotpot

definitely some raw seafood before we do the 
sauce there's a couple of things we need to do

for the noodles so I have drained it and now I'm 
going to cut it a couple of times just because if

not then it's really long and really difficult to 
deal with just with scissors and a couple of cuts

and finally the sauce so this sauce I have made a 
couple times now just for some friends and family

and a few people have come up to me to ask for 
the recipe because one it's very different from

the hot pot that you can get here in Canada so 
they've never had a sauce like this and it's

also just really really good there's a reason 
why it's so popular in Thailand okay and it's

quite easy all you need first is some garlic I'm 
just getting that down to very very fine so okay I

just have a garlic paste like that next ingredient 
is quite important it is what we call the houyi or

red bean curd it's a Chinese ingredient and I've 
used it several times on the show for one reason

or another and it's a fermented bean curd that's 
got a very unique smell to it and you want to just

grab out a couple of cubes they come in this like 
soft mushy cubes which I have completely erect

with my tongs you know what tongs probably not the 
best thing to use to grab these because it most

of them so let's try a spoon okay so that's the 
remainder of the first cube okay this is sort of

a cube kind of roughly like two tablespoons worth 
of stuff I want to add just a little bit of the

juice as well mash this up before I transfer this 
into a pot I'm going to add some toasted white

sesame seeds because I want a chance to crush 
it but you don't want to add the sesame seeds

whole because then the flavor is contained in the 
feet it's not coming out so you want to give it a

crush a light crush there you go and those still 
look whole but at least now they're broken up a

bit okay okay all this goes into the pot a big 
chunk of this is gonna be hot sauce so Sriracha

hot sauce so I am using just the popular rooster 
brand sriracha because I developed this recipe

using that because the most widely available one 
if you use a different brand of sriracha style

hot sauce you may have to adjust the amount of 
sugar and things a little bit because different

brands have different level of heat and sweetness 
and vinegar enos if you're using the Thai one for

example it's a lot sweeter and less spicy just as 
an example now we're also going to add the secret

ingredient ketchup yes we're not some ketchup to 
it and this will add tartness sweetness and just

general umami and so as you can see this is not 
a traditional Thai recipe but it won't taste like

ketchup by the end of it trust me boy stur sauce 
soy sauce toasted sesame oil this is key right

here a little bit of sugar and then some water 
to mellow everything out and then all I'm gonna

do is bring this to a simmer cook it for a couple 
minutes on low you don't want to reduce it just to

cook the garlic off a little bit and then you're 
done great thing about this sauce you can make

a whole bunch keep it in the fridge it basically 
lasts forever not literally but like a very long

okay that is done hotpot eating time so this 
is a little bizarre that I'm eating hotpot by

myself in front of a camera this is totally not 
the antithesis of what a hot pot meal should be

like where normally you'll have a lot of people 
around a pot so for the stock I'm just using plain

chicken stock I have a recipe I'll link to if you 
want like a more complex one but if you just boil

some chicken bones add a tiny bit of salt you're 
good to go now tools you want a hotpot ladle which

is this straining one so you can fish things 
out and then you want one of these per person

and then for the table you want a couple of 
soup ladles so to get some soup into your bowl

okay you want to first bring the pot bring the 
stock to a full boil because you're gonna dump

a bunch of stuff in it and it's gonna stop it's 
gonna cool down quite a bit so you want to start

out on a full boil it's now boiling vigorously 
the first things you want to add are all your

vegetables two reasons vegetables some of them 
can take a bit of time like the mushrooms also

vegetables will help flavor the broth so I just 
put in a bunch of communal vegetables the only

thing you want to watch for is a squash they do 
overcook so after about five minutes you kinda

have to keep an eye on them so they don't turn the 
entire pot yellow so once the vegetables are in

you want to put the glass no dose of course the 
glass noodles take about a couple of minutes in

boiling water and I like to keep my glass noodles 
in my sieve because if you put them in outside of

your sieve you will likely lose them forever you 
won't be able to find them again they'll end up

in the bottom of the pot so I just leave that in 
here and let it sit hot pot is actually one of

the healthiest meals you can have like in Thailand 
you know people who are on a diet or whatever they

enjoy a lot of hot pot because there's a lot of 
vegetables good protein and also the noodles in

hot pot is usually glass noodles right in glass 
noodles compared to wheat noodles or rice noodles

or even white rice it has lower glycemic index so 
if that's something that's a concern to you glass

noodles is the way to go with the meat what I like 
to do especially these like super super-thin it's

I don't even let it go like I literally dip for 
I don't know five ten seconds until it's cooked

and then I take it out and into my bowl it kind 
of like it's a little bit of a pet peeve for me

yes the stove is really hot it's a little bit 
of a pet peeve for me when I see people throw

in thinly sliced pieces of meat and then they 
just like let it hang out in the tub for like

three minutes and by the time you fish it out 
it's totally overcooked like this will take you

know ten seconds to cook great one thing you can 
add and just kind of let them go is all the fish

balls also you can add and they kind of last 
a long time in there you don't have to worry

too much about how long okay and what I like to 
do is my make I make myself a little bowl like

a little noodle soup bowl so I cook a bunch of 
stuff first and then I eat but some people like

to do the opposite where they just cook up cook 
to things eat the two things cook some more eat

I Coco Coco Coco and then I II dddd see how fun 
is this the only sad part is I'm by myself well

Adam is here but he's not participating right 
now okay I think that's a full bowl get a little

bit of soup the way you want to eat hotpot it's 
different for everybody whatever you like right

for some people they just take one piece dip 
and eat what I like to do is I put a little

bit of this sauce into my bowl and make sort of 
like a little soup that's some more broth here

make a little soup bowl and then I'll still 
dip in addition to that give a little dip dip

the important thing the noodles that sauce is 
everything it's sour sweet that flavor that

aroma of toasted sesame oil just a little bit of 
spiciness it's good on everything whatever you

dip it in here it will be good and the noodles 
a really really great texture that goes well

with the meat the vegetable is a great thing about 
glasses the reason why glass noodles is like the

noodles you want to use for hot pot is is a couple 
of reasons one it's a very neutral noodle that

goes well with everything it doesn't have much 
of a flavor in and of itself say compared to egg

noodles right so it's a great canvas for all sorts 
of flavor too when you cook the noodles in the

broth no starch leeches into the broth and muck 
it up if you try to cook rice noodles or try to

cook egg noodles in this broth eventually add that 
broth is gonna get murky so there's a reason why

glass widows the hot pot noodles that you want and 
it's just it just works so well with everything

the recipe as always will be on hot hsn.com when 
you make it send me a photo on Facebook Twitter

or Instagram and if you haven't subscribed to 
the show make sure you do so you don't miss an

episode like this and click the bell icon as 
well so you get a notification when it goes in

this video thank you as always for watching and 
I will see you next time for your next delicious
